articles.headline: Bridge Collapse in Minneapolis Kills at Least 7
articles.snippet: An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water.
articles.abstract: An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water.
articles.lead_paragraph: An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River last night, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water.
articles.byline: By Libby Sander and Susan Saulny

articles.headline: In Fox News, Giuliani Finds a Friendly Stage
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani is facing increased scrutiny over his friendship with Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani is facing increased scrutiny over his friendship with Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News.
articles.lead_paragraph: Roger Ailes and Rudolph W. Giuliani have been pulling for each other for nearly two decades.

articles.headline: Lead Paint Prompts Mattel to Recall 967,000 Toys
articles.snippet: The maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars is recalling the toys because of lead paint.
articles.abstract: The maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars is recalling the toys because of lead paint.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mattel, the maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars, is recalling nearly one million toys in the United States today because the products are covered in lead paint.

articles.headline: Caps on Prices Only Deepen Zimbabweans’ Misery
articles.snippet: One month after the government tried to allay the effects of hyperinflation, Zimbabwe’s economy is at a halt.
articles.abstract: One month after the government tried to allay the effects of hyperinflation, Zimbabwe’s economy is at a halt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe, July 28 — Robert G. Mugabe has ruled over this battered nation, his every wish endorsed by Parliament and enforced by the police and soldiers, for more than 27 years. It appears, however, that not even an unchallenged autocrat can repeal the laws of supply and demand.

articles.headline: The Side Deal in the Deal for Dow Jones
articles.snippet: Did the last-minute side deal for News Corporation to pay the Bancroft family’s advisers’ fees influence the advice the family received?
articles.abstract: Did the last-minute side deal for News Corporation to pay the Bancroft family’s advisers’ fees influence the advice the family received?
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, after months of debate within the Bancroft family about protecting the editorial independence of Dow Jones & Company, the discussion turned to a very different, 11th-hour, question: would Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation cover the Bancrofts’ legal and banker fees?
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Baseball Gets Into Resale of Tickets
articles.snippet: Major League Baseball has struck a revenue-sharing deal with StubHub to allow fans to resell or buy tickets online.
articles.abstract: Major League Baseball has struck a revenue-sharing deal with StubHub to allow fans to resell or buy tickets online.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 — Major League Baseball once frowned on scalping, the resale of tickets among fans and sidewalk entrepreneurs. On Thursday, professional baseball will announce plans to get into the business.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Get Your Free Net Phone Calls Here
articles.snippet: David Pogue explores the ins and outs of making free phone calls through the Internet.
articles.abstract: David Pogue explores the ins and outs of making free phone calls through the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The price of home phone service has dropped 30 percent since 1999. Surely, say the analysts, that trend line will eventually plummet all the way to zero. Surely, thanks to the Internet’s ability to carry your voice, landline phone calls will soon be free.

articles.headline: Surviving Without Subsidies
articles.snippet: Despite dire forecasts when the New Zealand government ended agricultural subsidies in the 1980s, the farming business there is now thriving.
articles.abstract: Despite dire forecasts when the New Zealand government ended agricultural subsidies in the 1980s, the farming business there is now thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: OHINEWAI, New Zealand — Watching grass grow is supposed to be dull. But watching it grow with a dairy farmer like Malcolm Lumsden is anything but.
